utterances: The president wants the government to keep making similar investments in long-term growth, even as he looks for ways to cut spending elsewhere in the federal budget.

the most competitive country in the world.
We know in GE, the future's given to no one.
We have to compete.
We have to win.
And I know that this team can compete with anybody in the world.
Unidentified Man #1: That's right.

We can absolutely do what it takes.
The president says he'll soon be announcing other members of the advisory panel, including labor leaders, economists and other business people.
He'll also have more to say about jobs and global competition in next week's State of the Union speech.
Scott Horsley, NPR News, the White House.
It's Day to Day from NPR News.
I'm Alex Chadwick.
And I'm Madeleine Brand.
Northern California is in the grips of one of the wettest years ever.
Record rainfall there has caused all kinds of problems, from delays in the local strawberry crop to flooding and mudslides.
And NPR's Richard Gonzales says residents are starting to wonder if they'll ever see the sun again.
First, the good news from The National Weather Service:
For Thursday night, mostly cloudy, chance of rain.
That's right, a chance of rain.
That's better than what we've been getting thus far, since it's rained nearly every day in April.
That's after the fifth wettest winter on record.
And April is a month when contractors such as Martin Coyle in Oakland expected to get his crews back to work.

Trying to do some trim on the outside of the building and we're also trying to build some fences up in the hills, and you dig a hole and it fills with water the next day and you've got to bail it out.
So it's just not working.
The bad news is that even if Mother Nature spared us another drop, it will take at least a week of sunny skies to mitigate the danger of mudslides.
Anxious owners of innumerable hillside homes are praying they won't suffer the same fate as 73-year-old Walter Guthrie of Mill Valley.
He's buried in the mudslide that hit his home early Wednesday morning.
It's about 30 yards wide by 12 to 15 feet deep, and it probably goes up another 30 to 40 yards up the drainage.
Greg Moore is the battalion chief of the Mill Valley Fire Department.
He had a crew of 80 digging through the mound of mud by hand, because the slope wasn't accessible by large machines.
Many times, people have been caught in avalanches or landslides and live for a couple days.
You know, it's cold, it's wet out here.
There are places there could be air pockets, so it's still a rescue operation.
But a few hours later, the rescue was called off and workers shifted their attention to recovering Walter Guthrie's body.
Further south, authorities are monitoring the swollen San Joaquin River, where there is concern about possible breaks in a network of levees.
And in the Sierra, snow is falling, making travel hazardous.
But the bigger danger may come later this year, authorities say, when the heavy snow melts, producing another round of flooding.
Forecasters say the sun will return but probably not until next week.
Richard Gonzales, NPR News, San Francisco.
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
Remember the good old days when every Hello Kitty diary had an actual, real-life lock on it?
Well, not only have the times changed, every change has been logged.
Daily documentation has become routine for the tech savvy to connect with everyone, anyone, anytime.
Blogs are practically pass√©.

Welcome to a new world of vlogs, MySpace, Flickr, and now life-logging, a system that documents every conversation, movement, and idea through a series of recording gadgets like cameras, GPS trackers, even brain scanners.
Constant exposure is of course a double-edge sword.
Online diarists and life-loggers must be prepared for humiliation as well as fame; and in this day and age, they're often the same thing.
And it's creating a generation gap between those who prefer to keep their blinds closed and those who love a glass house and are not afraid to play catch with stones.
Coming up later in the program, Hollywood snubs the Valentine spirits says one commentator.
But first, life-logging and the generation gap over privacy.
How much of your life do you put online?
Are you a diehard logger and online archiver?
If so, why?

Our e-mail address is talk@npr.org.
And our first guest is Emily Nussbaum, contributing editor of New York magazine and the author of New York magazine's look into the online world, where virtually everything is exposed.
She joins us from our bureau in New York.
Thanks for struggling in through the snow.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Thank you.

(Reading) "Any ruler who refuses to cooperate will be regarded as Rome's enemy.
Those who are not with us are against us.
Martha Hughes Cannon as a young girl came across the plains with a group of Mormon pioneers and settled in Salt Lake City.
This is Becky Edwards, Republican state representative.
She carried the bill to send Martha Hughes Cannon to Washington.
When she ran for a political office - this was in 1896, when Utah first became a state - she ran both against her husband, Angus Cannon, and her best friend.
And she beat them both.
Martha was the first woman elected state senator in the country.
She was also a polygamist and the fourth of Angus Cannon's six wives.
She and many other women in Utah advocated for universal women's suffrage.
Utah first enfranchised women in 1870, 50 years before the 19th Amendment gave all American women the right to vote.
But somehow, Utah slipped from the leading edge of women's rights all the way to the back of the pack when it comes to measuring women's advancement.
The worst place for women in business, the worst place for women in politics, the worst place for women medically.
Neylan McBaine leads a grassroots group in Utah called Better Days 2020 that pushed hard for Martha's statue.
She also notes that Utah is tied with Louisiana for the worst pay gap in the country.
Her group is backed by some big Utah businesses that have trouble recruiting people from out of state.

These corporations are highly invested in changing the narrative about Utah women, in changing the way that Utah women perceive themselves and also the way that people outside of Utah perceive Utah women.
For instance, Salt Lake City is renaming streets after suffragists.
Utah has a new license plate that says first to vote.
Wyoming women technically got the right to vote first, but Utah had an election first.
McBaine's group is also writing a new curriculum for elementary and middle schools about Utah women's history.
We're putting our faith in the power of history to change perspective and identity.
While history is one way to tackle inequality in Utah, I wondered during a phone conversation with Becky Edwards, the Utah state representative, if there might be a quicker way.
Well, You could also just legislate equal pay.
(Laughter) Yes, we could (laughter).
But, well, that's one of the reasons why we need more women in office.
In fact, Martha Hughes Cannon and the women of Utah were advocating for equal pay for equal work in the 1800s.
Martha's statue will come to Washington in two years, on the 100th anniversary of the 19th Amendment.
For NPR News, I'm Dianna Douglas.
Senior producer Steve Proffitt joins us now to share some of your letters.
Steve, welcome back.
Thanks, Alex.
